Problem

Description of the problem.

Given: A formalised input with xs as input.

Return: A formlised output with ys as output.

Sample Dataset

AGCTTTTCATTCTGACTGCAACGGGCAATATGTCTCTGTGTGGATTAAAAAAAGAGTGTCTGATAGCAGC

Sample Output

20 12 17 21

Welcome to Rosalind!

Rosalind is a platform for learning bioinformatics through problem solving.
Please login with Google/Twitter/Facebook or register a new account.

A Typical Problem Statement

Every Rosalind problem begins with an introduction detailing a practical issue in biology.
Click to expand the biological introduction to this problem.

Important Terms are Highlighted

Hover over a highlighted term to see a short definition of the term.
Click on the term to see a popup window containing a more in-depth description.

Next

Figures Give Extra Information

Click to see an illustration of the topic at hand, possibly with more explanation.

Next

Getting Down to Business

Now that you understand the biological background, here is a computational problem that applies to it.

Next

Sample Dataset

The Sample Dataset/Sample Output sections show you how the dataset will be given and exactly how you should format your answer. Answers not in the format of the Sample Output will be counted as incorrect.

Next

Design and Implement Your Solution

Prepare a solution for a general dataset. Solving Rosalind problems requires programming. If you have any difficulties with this problem, here is a solution in Python. A Python tutorial can be found here.

I'm ready to try a real dataset!

Ready...set...

If you have coded a solution for an arbitrary dataset, click here to download the dataset in the form of a .txt file.
You'll have 5 minutes to upload your answer. You may make an unlimited number of attempts without being penalized, but you will receive a new dataset with each new attempt.

Upload Your Answer

Either upload a text file containing your answer below, or simply paste your answer in this field. After submitting your solution, you may choose to upload your code below as well.

Congratulations!

Go ahead, try to become a Bioinformatics Guru.

The goal of Rosalind is to facilitate learning through problem solving. We encourage you to search the Internet or communicate with each other to find the best algorithms to solve our problem.

However, there is a difference between looking for inspiration and copy-pasting someone else's code; we strongly advise you not to use others' source code. Once you have solved a problem, we encourage you to post your code to the problem's comments section (which can be seen only by users who have also solved the problem. However, please do not publish your code outside of the Rosalind website.

Okay
